messages.text: Hi! Me again. It is getting better, I can add variables to my models now. Here I face a small design trouble. My variables domains are pretty versatile (it doesn't even have to be scalars ...). For a first simple version, I would like to cover two scalar cases. Continuous and discrete domains. Continuous domain should be fine with MOI/JuMP tools. Integral domain also, but it is only a subset of  discrete domains. Is there a clean (or less clean) way of defining `x \in DiscreteSet` through MOI?

messages.text: Hi. Continuing on a question I posted yesterday about SumOfSquares, I am doing `JuMP.optimize!(model)`  on a `SOSModel(solver)`. The problem I have is actually a family of problems with a parameter. I vary the parameter through a certain range. The optimization goes fine for most of them, but for some values it goes awry and gives me an unexpected and wrong result, although it says that it reached a `FEASIBLE_POINT`. So my question might be more general than for SOS model: is it possible to initialize the optimization so I could start with the values found for the previous parameter, as in a continuation method?

messages.text: ping <@UCT7E536E> for a PreSolve GSOC

Hi there, I have another question. I am trying to run `JuMP.optimize!` with my solver. Which try to make a ref between JuMP variables and the solver variables. In the process, it raises the following error: `no method matching setindex!(::MathOptInterface.Utilities.IndexMap, ::Int64, ::MathOptInterface.ConstraintIndex{MathOptInterface.VectorOfVariables, LocalSearchSolvers.AllDifferent})` I guess I am missing something, but I don't know how to define `setindex` from here.

text.text:
Hi there, I have another question. I am trying to run `JuMP.optimize!` with my solver. Which try to make a ref between JuMP variables and the solver variables. In the process, it raises the following error:
`no method matching setindex!(::MathOptInterface.Utilities.IndexMap, ::Int64, ::MathOptInterface.ConstraintIndex{MathOptInterface.VectorOfVariables, LocalSearchSolvers.AllDifferent})`
I guess I am missing something, but I don't know how to define `setindex` from here.

messages.text: Based on the code I could find in MOI.jl, it seems that the function `setindex!` is extended in `Utilities/copy.jl` as follows: ``` Base.setindex!(idxmap::IndexMap, vi1::MOI.VariableIndex, vi2::MOI.VariableIndex) = Base.setindex!(idxmap.varmap, vi1, vi2) function Base.setindex!(idxmap::IndexMap, ci1::MOI.ConstraintIndex{F, S}, ci2::MOI.ConstraintIndex{F, S}) where {F, S}     Base.setindex!(idxmap.conmap, ci1, ci2) end ``` I probably need to extend it for my custom set. I welcome any hint!

text.text:
Based on the code I could find in MOI.jl, it seems that the function `setindex!` is extended in `Utilities/copy.jl` as follows:
```
Base.setindex!(idxmap::IndexMap, vi1::MOI.VariableIndex, vi2::MOI.VariableIndex) = Base.setindex!(idxmap.varmap, vi1, vi2)
function Base.setindex!(idxmap::IndexMap, ci1::MOI.ConstraintIndex{F, S}, ci2::MOI.ConstraintIndex{F, S}) where {F, S}
    Base.setindex!(idxmap.conmap, ci1, ci2)
end
```
I probably need to extend it for my custom set. I welcome any hint!

messages.text: I just saw the messages! Sorry. I can now do: ``` function sudoku_jump(n)     N = n^2     m = JuMP.Model(CBLS.Optimizer)      @variable(m, X[1:N, 1:N], DiscreteSet(1:N))      for i in 1:N         @constraint(m, X[i,:] in AllDifferent(N)) # rows         @constraint(m, X[:,i] in AllDifferent(N)) # columns     end     for i in 1:n, j in 1:n         @constraint(m, vec(X[(i+1):(i+n), (j+1):(j+n)]) in AllDifferent(N)) # blocks     end     return m end  # Solve a sudoku 9x9 JuMP.optimize!(sudoku(3)) ``` Which is pretty cool.  There is a bit of a not necessary part in this syntax for CP solvers when we use a global constraint (the function applied is defined on a vector of any size, not on a fixed size vector). So having a dimension argument is absolutely not necessary. Would it be OK to make an issue/PR in JuMP to allow dimension as `nothing` so that when the dimension is nothing the vector just have to be of size > 0 ? Then I could write `AllDifferent()`

text.text:
I just saw the messages! Sorry. I can now do:
```
function sudoku_jump(n)
    N = n^2
    m = JuMP.Model(CBLS.Optimizer)

    @variable(m, X[1:N, 1:N], DiscreteSet(1:N))

    for i in 1:N
        @constraint(m, X[i,:] in AllDifferent(N)) # rows
        @constraint(m, X[:,i] in AllDifferent(N)) # columns
    end
    for i in 1:n, j in 1:n
        @constraint(m, vec(X[(i+1):(i+n), (j+1):(j+n)]) in AllDifferent(N)) # blocks
    end
    return m
end

# Solve a sudoku 9x9
JuMP.optimize!(sudoku(3))
```
Which is pretty cool.

There is a bit of a not necessary part in this syntax for CP solvers when we use a global constraint (the function applied is defined on a vector of any size, not on a fixed size vector). So having a dimension argument is absolutely not necessary.
Would it be OK to make an issue/PR in JuMP to allow dimension as `nothing` so that when the dimension is nothing the vector just have to be of size > 0 ?
Then I could write `AllDifferent()`

messages.text: Even though it doesn't seem to annoying with AllDifferent, one can define a constraint with one or more parameters. Having the length of the input vector out of the picture in these cases will be great

messages.text: See examples like <https://github.com/jump-dev/JuMP.jl/blob/e25dd2045291a9e9ed4b5b839a68e4f5eb84a432/src/sets.jl#L77-L103>.  You want something like  ``` struct MOIAllDifferent <: MOI.AbstractVectorSet     N::Int end struct AllDifferent <: JuMP.AbstractVectorSet end JuMP.moi_set(::AllDifferent, dim::Int) = MOIAllDifferent(dim)  @constraint(model, x in AllDifferent()) @constraint(model, x in MOIAllDifferent(3)) ```

text.text:
See examples like <https://github.com/jump-dev/JuMP.jl/blob/e25dd2045291a9e9ed4b5b839a68e4f5eb84a432/src/sets.jl#L77-L103>.

You want something like 
```
struct MOIAllDifferent <: MOI.AbstractVectorSet
    N::Int
end
struct AllDifferent <: JuMP.AbstractVectorSet end
JuMP.moi_set(::AllDifferent, dim::Int) = MOIAllDifferent(dim)

@constraint(model, x in AllDifferent())
@constraint(model, x in MOIAllDifferent(3))
```

messages.text: Hi there! I'm back with another matter (I promise, I'm getting close to my  objective ...) I am trying to define objectives that use arbitrary functions. The two cases I would like to cover are as follow. ``` # Assuming DistExtrema is predefined function that accepts X as input @objective(m, Min, X, DistExtrema())  # Arbitrary function `func` that accepts X as input  @objective(m, Min, X, ArbitraryObjective(func)) ``` Of course the syntax can be different, but I suppose you can get the main idea. Is it possible with the current `@objective` macro to do something similar?

text.text:
Hi there! I'm back with another matter (I promise, I'm getting close to my  objective ...)
I am trying to define objectives that use arbitrary functions. The two cases I would like to cover are as follow.
```
# Assuming DistExtrema is predefined function that accepts X as input
@objective(m, Min, X, DistExtrema())

# Arbitrary function `func` that accepts X as input
 @objective(m, Min, X, ArbitraryObjective(func))
```
Of course the syntax can be different, but I suppose you can get the main idea. Is it possible with the current `@objective` macro to do something similar?

messages.text: I am also OK with extending `@objective` locally to my solver as the difference between linear and NLP is often meaningless for Constraint Programming solvers. I am no idea of the amount of work involved though

messages.text: @azzaare thinking more on this, you should define a new `MOI.AbstractFunction` and overload <https://github.com/jump-dev/JuMP.jl/blob/0205c98956d41dae667878dd120717c1d188f861/src/objective.jl#L81-L91>. Not sure if the `@objective` macro will work. It probably needs `@objective(model, Min, ArbitraryObjective(func, X))`.

text.text: @azzaare thinking more on this, you should define a new `MOI.AbstractFunction` and overload <https://github.com/jump-dev/JuMP.jl/blob/0205c98956d41dae667878dd120717c1d188f861/src/objective.jl#L81-L91>. Not sure if the `@objective` macro will work. It probably needs `@objective(model, Min, ArbitraryObjective(func, X))`.

messages.text: @manojcen start by reading the first post of <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/psa-make-it-easier-to-help-you/14757>, then make a post on the community forum with a minimal reproducible exmaple: <https://discourse.julialang.org/c/domain/opt/13>. GLPK should support `CallbackNodeStatus`. You need `import Pkg; Pkg.add("GLPK")` to be at least `0.14.4`.

attachments.title: PSA: make it easier to help you
attachments.text: Welcome to the Julia Discourse! We are enthusiastic about helping Julia programmers, both beginner and experienced. This public service announcement (PSA) outlines best practices when asking for help. Following these points makes it easier for us to help you and more likely you’ll get a prompt, useful answer. If you were referred to this wiki page in the course of solving a problem, it is recommended that you just read the first post, and ignore the discussion below. Keywords are highlighted to...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: PSA: make it easier to help you

attachments.title: Optimization (Mathematical)
attachments.text: For discussion of mathematical optimization software in Julia. This includes modeling software and solvers for linear optimization, mixed-integer optimization, convex optimization, nonlinear optimization, semidefinite optimization, and related topics.

text.text: @manojcen start by reading the first post of <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/psa-make-it-easier-to-help-you/14757>, then make a post on the community forum with a minimal reproducible exmaple: <https://discourse.julialang.org/c/domain/opt/13>. GLPK should support `CallbackNodeStatus`. You need `import Pkg; Pkg.add("GLPK")` to be at least `0.14.4`.

messages.text: thanks again @odow . I have made some progress, at least the MOI part works perfectly. I have some trouble to progress further, which is mainly due to my low undertsanding on how JuMP and MOI interact. I reach a point where I am not sure if I made a mistep in my implementation of the MOI functions or if I need to implement something else.

messages.text: If someone has a small amount of time to check what is the problem, I would be very greatful. Briefly, here is the StackTrace that be obtained by launching tests on the `objective` branch of LocalSearchSolvers.jl (cf  [PR#57](<https://github.com/JuliaConstraints/LocalSearchSolvers.jl/pull/57>)). The code related to this objective things is the `ScalarFunction` in [objectives.jl](<https://github.com/JuliaConstraints/LocalSearchSolvers.jl/blob/objective/src/MOI_wrapper/objectives.jl>). If no one has time, I will try to come back on it after some break!

If no one has time, I will try to come back on it after some break!
